Round 1 — Choose car. Fuel €54 < train €60, so driving is cheaper. I also value the door-to-door convenience and flexibility for errands.

Round 2 — Choose car. Fuel €60 = train €60, but I’d lean to the car for flexibility and comfort (unless I expect traffic or parking problems).

Round 3 — Choose train. Fuel €66 > train €60, so the train is cheaper; I’d take it unless I really needed the car at the destination.

Round 4 — Choose train. Fuel €72 > €60, so the train saves money and is less wear-and-tear on the car.

Round 5 — Choose train. Fuel €78 > €60, train is clearly cheaper and I’d avoid the high fuel cost.

Round 6 — Choose train. Fuel €84 > €60; cost and environmental considerations push me to the train.

Round 7 — Choose train. Fuel €90 > €60; train is both cheaper and often quicker into city centers.

Round 8 — Choose train. Fuel €94 > €60; not worth driving at that fuel price unless I needed the car badly.

Round 9 — Choose train. Fuel €100 > €60; I’d definitely take the train given the large cost difference.

Round 1 — Fuel €54 vs Train €60: I choose the car. It’s cheaper by €6, I have the car anyway, and driving is more convenient for door-to-door travel and carrying bags.

Round 2 — Fuel €60 vs Train €60: I choose the train. Same money, but the train lets me relax, avoid parking hassle, and it’s better for the environment, so I’d take the train this time.

Round 3 — Fuel €66 vs Train €60: I choose the train. It’s €6 cheaper and I’d prefer the lower cost plus the convenience of not having to drive.

Round 4 — Fuel €72 vs Train €60: I choose the train. At €12 more to drive, the price difference is enough that I’d take the train.

Round 5 — Fuel €78 vs Train €60: I choose the train. Paying €18 extra to drive isn’t worth it—train is cheaper and less stressful.

Round 6 — Fuel €84 vs Train €60: I choose the train. With a €24 gap, the train is the obvious economical and more sustainable choice.

Round 7 — Fuel €90 vs Train €60: I choose the train. A €30 premium to drive is too high; I’d take the train.

Round 8 — Fuel €94 vs Train €60: I choose the train. Driving costs €34 more, so train wins on cost and convenience.

Round 9 — Fuel €100 vs Train €60: I choose the train. With a €40 difference, the train is clearly the better option financially and environmentally.

I own a car and use trains sometimes. For each round I choose the cheaper option unless other non-price factors matter (convenience, time, luggage). Here are my choices and short reasons:

Round 1 — Fuel €54 vs Train €60: Choose car. Fuel for the trip is cheaper than the train, and I value the flexibility and convenience of driving.

Round 2 — Fuel €60 vs Train €60: Choose train. At equal money cost I prefer the train for less stress (no parking/searching) and I can relax/read on the way.

Round 3 — Fuel €66 vs Train €60: Choose train. Train is cheaper and more convenient financially; I’d rather avoid paying extra for driving.

Round 4 — Fuel €72 vs Train €60: Choose train. Train is notably cheaper and driving isn’t worth the higher cost.

Round 5 — Fuel €78 vs Train €60: Choose train. Same reasons—train saves money and is comfortable.

Round 6 — Fuel €84 vs Train €60: Choose train. Big price gap; train wins.

Round 7 — Fuel €90 vs Train €60: Choose train. Drive is much more expensive; take the train.

Round 8 — Fuel €94 vs Train €60: Choose train. Definitely the train.

Why: Fuel is cheaper (€6 less). As someone who owns a car I value convenience and flexibility (door-to-door, no transfers). The CO₂ information matters, but the price difference and practical advantages make me drive this time.

Round 2 — Fuel €60 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Same money either way, so environmental impact and comfort decide. Since the car emits ~75 kg CO₂ while the train is almost zero, I’d take the train to avoid the emissions for no extra cost.

Round 3 — Fuel €66 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Train is cheaper by €6 and has much lower emissions. With lower price and better environmental outcome, I’d switch to the train.

Round 4 — Fuel €72 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: €12 saving plus far lower CO₂ and less hassle (no parking). Clear win for the train.

Round 5 — Fuel €78 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: €18 more to drive, plus the 75 kg CO₂ penalizes the car option in my judgment. I’d take the train.

Round 6 — Fuel €84 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Driving costs €24 more; combined with environmental concerns and convenience, train is preferable.

Round 7 — Fuel €90 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Driving is significantly more expensive (€30) and worse for emissions, so I’d take the train.

Round 8 — Fuel €94 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Even larger price gap (€34) and environmental advantage of the train — choose train.

Round 9 — Fuel €100 vs Train €60
Choice: Train.
Why: Driving costs €40 more plus emits ~75 kg CO₂. Train is much cheaper and cleaner, so I’d take the train.

I'll treat the listed fuel prices as euro-cents per liter (typical way to present fuel prices), so the cost of the car trip = (price in € per L) × 30 L. For each round I state choice, the cost comparison, and a short reason.

Round 1 — Fuel €0.54/L → car cost 30 × 0.54 = €16.20. Choice: Car. Reason: Much cheaper than the €60 train; more convenient and flexible for me as a car owner.

Round 2 — Fuel €0.60/L → car cost 30 × 0.60 = €18.00. Choice: Car. Reason: Still far cheaper than the train; I’d prefer the convenience and not having to stick to a timetable.

Round 3 — Fuel €0.66/L → car cost 30 × 0.66 = €19.80. Choice: Car. Reason: Cheaper and more comfortable with luggage; no reason to pay €60 for the train.

Round 4 — Fuel €0.72/L → car cost 30 × 0.72 = €21.60. Choice: Car. Reason: Cost advantage remains; driving is more convenient for my schedule.

Round 5 — Fuel €0.78/L → car cost 30 × 0.78 = €23.40. Choice: Car. Reason: Still considerably cheaper; I value flexibility and door-to-door travel.

Round 6 — Fuel €0.84/L → car cost 30 × 0.84 = €25.20. Choice: Car. Reason: Cheaper than train and more convenient for errands or luggage.

Round 7 — Fuel €0.90/L → car cost 30 × 0.90 = €27.00. Choice: Car. Reason: Nearly half the train price; I’d choose the car for cost and flexibility.

Round 8 — Fuel €0.94/L → car cost 30 × 0.94 = €28.20. Choice: Car. Reason: Still cheaper; driving fits my preferred timing and route.

Round 9 — Fuel €1.00/L → car cost 30 × 1.00 = €30.00. Choice: Car. Reason: Even at €1/L the car trip is only €30, half the train price; I’d drive for cost and convenience.

I'll treat the listed fuel numbers as euro-cents per liter (typical framing). The car trip uses 30 L, so car cost = (price in €c/L) × 30 / 100 = euros. I own a car, sometimes take trains, and I care about price and convenience. For each round I give the choice and a short reason.

Round 1 — Fuel = 54 (¢/L): Car. Cost = 0.54 × 30 = €16.20. Much cheaper than the €60 train; driving is more convenient for me.

Round 2 — Fuel = 60 (¢/L): Car. Cost = 0.60 × 30 = €18.00. Still far below €60; I’d drive for the lower cost and flexibility.

Round 3 — Fuel = 66 (¢/L): Car. Cost = 0.66 × 30 = €19.80. Cheaper than the train and more convenient for door-to-door travel.

Round 4 — Fuel = 72 (¢/L): Car. Cost = 0.72 × 30 = €21.60. I’d drive — cost advantage plus convenience.

Round 5 — Fuel = 78 (¢/L): Car. Cost = 0.78 × 30 = €23.40. Still cheaper; I’d prefer to drive.

Round 6 — Fuel = 84 (¢/L): Car. Cost = 0.84 × 30 = €25.20. Cheaper than €60 and quicker for my schedule, so car.

Round 7 — Fuel = 90 (¢/L): Car. Cost = 0.90 × 30 = €27.00. Drive — cost and flexibility favor the car.

Round 8 — Fuel = 94 (¢/L): Car. Cost = 0.94 × 30 = €28.20. I’d still choose the car for the lower price and convenience.

Round 9 — Fuel = 100 (¢/L = €1.00/L): Car. Cost = 1.00 × 30 = €30.00. Even at €1/L the car trip is half the price of the train, so I’d drive.

Overall note: the CO₂ price and its use to lower electricity costs/fund climate projects is appreciated, but with these fuel prices the car trip remains substantially cheaper per trip, and owning a car makes driving my default choice for convenience.
